clinical_study.brief_title: Comparative Effectiveness of Ultrasound and Paraffin Therapy in Patients With Carpal Tunnel Syndrome: A Randomized Trial
clinical_study.official_title: Comparative Effectiveness of Ultrasound and Paraffin Therapy in Patients With Carpal Tunnel Syndrome: A Randomized Trial

lead_sponsor.agency: Taipei Tzu Chi Hospital, Buddhist Tzu Chi Medical Foundation

clinical_study.source: Taipei Tzu Chi Hospital, Buddhist Tzu Chi Medical Foundation

brief_summary.textblock: The purpose of this study is to compare the efficacy of combining a wrist orthosis with either ultrasound therapy or paraffin bath therapy in treating carpal tunnel syndrome patients.

detailed_description.textblock: The purpose of this exploratory study is to compare the combination of a wrist orthosis with either ultrasound therapy or paraffin bath therapy in the treatment of carpal tunnel syndrome patients. We hypothesized that ultrasound therapy might be more effective than paraffin therapy because it provides both thermal and nonthermal effects.

primary_outcome.measure: functional status scale of the Boston carpal tunnel syndrome questionnaire

secondary_outcome.measure: symptom severity scale of the Boston carpal tunnel syndrome questionnaire
changes in the monofilament sensory test
changes in the distal sensory latencies of the median nerve
changes in the distal motor latencies of the median nerve

arm_group.description: Patients in the ultrasound therapy group were treated with US therapy for 5 minutes each session, twice per week for 8 weeks.

Patients in the paraffin therapy group were treated with the dip-and-wrap method of paraffin bath therapy in the hospital twice per week for 8 weeks. The temperature of the paraffin bath was maintained at approximately 55°C

intervention.description: Patients in the ultrasound therapy group were treated with US therapy for 5 minutes each session, twice per week for 8 weeks.

Patients in the paraffin therapy group were treated with the dip-and-wrap method of paraffin bath therapy in the hospital twice per week for 8 weeks. The temperature of the paraffin bath was maintained at approximately 55°C

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- patients to have subjective symptoms (such as pain and/or numbness in the median nerve distribution of the digits or nocturnal pain). Furthermore, patients were required to have either a positive Phalen's sign or a positive Tinel's sign along with electrophysiological evidence of carpal tunnel syndrome.
Exclusion Criteria:
- (1) age younger than 18 years old; (2) underlying medical disorders, such as diabetes mellitus, renal failure, autoimmune disease or hypothyroidism; and (3) pregnancy, previous wrist trauma or surgery.
